questions.text: A young patient is admitted to your hospital with acute psychosis. He wakes up and asks for his wife even though she is present in the same room. Upon seeing her, he starts beating her, accusing her of being a nurse, masquerading as his wife. He also says that the nurse was trying to give him the wrong medication in an attempt to harm him. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Capgras syndrome

In the given scenario the patient thinks that the nurse (persecutor/stranger) has taken the guise of the wife (family person). This is characteristic of Capgras syndrome.

questions.text: A teacher demonstrated the steps of handwashing to her students. Students also performed the same activity later at school and at home. What is the type of learning in this case?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Psychomotor

The type of learning seen in this case is psychomotor learning. The psychomotor domain includes learning by observation, physical movements, and the usage of motor skill areas of the brain. The development of these skills requires practice, depending upon the complexity of the task. It is measured based on speed, precision, distance, and procedures in execution

questions.text: A 40-year-old psychiatric patient is admitted for electroconvulsive therapy. He is likely to be suffering from which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Major depression with psychosis

The patient is likely to be suffering from major depression with psychosis, which is an indication for electroconvulsive therapy. Electroconvulsive therapy (ECT) involves inducing a bilateral generalized seizure in an anesthetized patient using an electrical current.

questions.text: A young man presented with a 2-week history of auditory hallucinations and delusions of grandiosity. His history is significant for severe depression with psychotic symptoms. However, he has been euthymic for the past month. According to DSM-5, what would be the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Schizoaffective disorder

The given clinical scenario points toward the diagnosis of schizoaffective disorder

questions.text: An employee in a company is friends with everyone in his office. He goes to different parties every weekend and says he loves talking to new people. This trait is described under which dimension of personality?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Extraversion

The traits of being talkative, sociable, and outgoing are described under extraversion. It is one of the five personality traits of the big five personality theory. It indicates how outgoing and social a person is

questions.text: A schizophrenic patient was started on an antipsychotic drug that decreased his hallucinations significantly. Three days after starting the medication, he developed torticollis and orofacio-lingual movements. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Acute muscular dystonia

The patient has developed acute muscular dystonia (spasm of muscles of tongue, face, neck, and back) which is an extrapyramidal side effect of haloperidol. This occurs within 1-5 days of drug intake.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man complained of low mood, decreased appetite, and loss of weight for the past 2 months. He mentions that he feels worthless and has decreased interest in activities. He also complains of great difficulty falling asleep. He has past history of atrial fibrillation. Which of the following drugs should be preferred for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Mirtazapine

The patient in the given clinical scenario has major depression with insomnia, decreased appetite, and weight loss. The preferred drug for this patient is mirtazapine as it is an antidepressant with sedative and appetite-stimulating properties.

questions.text: What is the minimum duration of period to diagnose post-traumatic stress disorder in a patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

 In post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD), the symptoms persist for more than one month.

questions.text: What is ‘mental retardation’ now called according to the American Psychiatric Association in its revision of DSM-5?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Mental retardation is now known as Intellectual Disability. According to the revised DSM-5, by the American Psychiatrist Association.

questions.text: Which of the following is the drug of choice that you will prescribe for a patient with a generalised anxiety disorder?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) like sertraline are the drug of choice in the treatment of generalised anxiety disorder. CBT is advised along with SSRIs. Buspirone is a second-line drug used in generalized anxiety disorder.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common psychiatric comorbidity that you would expect to find in a patient with anorexia nervosa?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

 Depression is the most common psychiatric comorbidity seen in patients with anorexia nervosa. Overall, anorexia nervosa is associated with depression in 65% of cases, social phobia in 35% of cases, and obsessive- compulsive disorder in 25% of cases.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman has been taking medication (the name of which she does not remember) for her psychiatric condition. She complains of excessive thirst and urinating “all the time.” Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Bipolar disorder 

This patient has symptoms of diabetes insipidus, a side effect of lithium used in the treatment of bipolar disease.

choices.text: Belief that one has the power of an alien species

questions.text: A 54-year-old, psychotic, homeless man is brought into the emergency department by the police for medical clearance, after being picked up for aggressive behavior and disorderly conduct. He has a history of alcoholism, substance abuse, as well as poorly controlled diabetes and hypertension. Which of the following symptoms is most specific to a diagnosis of schizophrenia, as opposed to other etiologies of psychosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Belief that one has the power of an alien species 

Although all these symptoms can be seen in various psychotic disorders, the presence of a bizarre delusion is the most specific to schizophrenia. Only one psychotic symptom is needed to diagnose schizophrenia if there are bizarre delusions, auditory hallucinations commenting on the patient, or two or more voices speaking to each other.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a treatment option in alcohol withdrawal delirium?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Antipsychotics 

Antipsychotics are not the treatment option of alcohol withdrawal delirium. Antipsychotic medications may reduce the seizure threshold in these patients and should be avoided. The best treatment for delirium tremens is prevention. Patients withdrawing from alcohol who exhibit withdrawal phenomena should receive benzodiazepines, such as 25 to 50 mg of chlordiazepoxide every 2 to 4 hours until they seem to be out of danger.

questions.text: A 34-year-old female presented to the psychiatric OPD with low mood, loss of energy, loss of interest in pleasurable activities, decreased sleep, and appetite for the past 2 months. What is the most appropriate treatment to be started?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Fluoxetine

The clinical vignette point towards major depressive disorder. SSRIs like fluoxetine are the most appropriate treatment for major depressive disorder. SSRIs should be continued for 6-9 months after complete remission of symptoms in case of a single episode of depression.

questions.text: A patient was brought to the emergency room with complaints of inability to walk or lift his left leg for the past 2 days. History and physical examination were unremarkable. However, he did not seem concerned about his condition. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Conversion disorder

The absence of concern towards one's problem despite an apparent severe disability is known as La-belle indifference. It is seen in conversion disorder.

questions.text: A 64-year-old man was brought to the casualty with confusion and gait instability. Medical history is significant for alcohol use disorder, requiring multiple hospitalizations in the past. On examination, he appears inattentive, has bilateral horizontal nystagmus, and his gait is slow and wide-based. What is the next step in management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Give thiamine injection

The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Wernicke's encephalopathy, which is a medical emergency. Thiamine administration (100 mg IV or IM for 3 days followed by two to three times a day orally for 1 to 2 weeks) may reduce the risk of it progressing to chronic Korsakoff psychosis which is irreversible.

questions.text: What is defined as the emotional release and discharge after consciously reliving a painful experience that has been repressed?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Abreaction is a psychoanalytical term for reliving an experience to release it emotionally. It is a specific type of catharsis done by becoming conscious of repressed traumatic events.

questions.text: A 28-year-old female presents with disorganized speech characterized by a lack of logical connection between thoughts. Her sentences often seem unrelated and do not follow a coherent train of thought. Which of the following best describes this symptom?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

In this scenario, the patient's disorganized speech with a lack of logical connection between thoughts is characteristic of "loose associations". This symptom is often seen in conditions like schizophrenia, where there is a disruption in the normal flow of thought and a breakdown in the logical progression of ideas. The person's sentences may seem unrelated or jump from one topic to another without a clear connection.

questions.text: What is the most likely cause of a patient with a history of schizophrenia, taking a second-generation antipsychotic medication for the past month, presenting with intense inner restlessness, an inability to sit still, constantly shifting in chair, and a strong urge to keep moving?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

The clinical presentation of the patient, including the subjective feeling of restlessness, and objective signs of motor restlessness such as rocking motions, pacing around, and rapid alteration of sitting and standing, is consistent with akathisia. Akathisia is a common side effect of antipsychotic medications and is characterized by intense inner restlessness and an inability to sit still.
